org.fern.rest.android
Class ArrayAdapter<T>

java.lang.Object
  
      org.fern.rest.android.ArrayAdapter<T>
Type Parameters:
T - The type of Array that the adapter will store.
Direct Known Subclasses:
AccountListAdapter, TaskAdapter
public class ArrayAdapter<T>
extends

This method is a wrapper for the @see android.widget.ArrayAdapter class. It was written to add some extra functionality to the class, for easier list item manipulation.

It was chosen not to support T[] type arguments, because they are more difficult to manipulate later on. List<T> objects are very easily manipulated, however.

Author:
Sergio Enriquez, Andrew Hays

ArrayAdapter

public ArrayAdapter(Context context,
                    int textViewResourceId,
                    java.util.List<T> objects)
This constructor is used for creating an ArrayAdapter with a preset list.

Parameters:
context - A context provider for accessing the application.
textViewResourceId - The resource to use for adding items to the @see android.view.View.
objects - The objects that are going to be added to the ArrayAdapter.

ArrayAdapter

public ArrayAdapter(Context context,
                    int textViewResourceId)
This method is for using a blank list to start out. This should be preferred for the use of filling a list afterwards.

Parameters:
context - A context provider for accessing the application.
textViewResourceId - The resource to use for adding items to the @see android.view.View.
Method Detail

addAll

public void addAll(java.util.List<T> items)
Adds an entire list of items to the collection. Unfortunately, this must go through each item individually to add it, since addAll wasn't introduced to the Android framework until SDK 11

Parameters:
items - The list of items to add to the collection.

setList

public void setList(java.util.List<T> items)
Resets the list to the list of given items.

Parameters:
items - The list of items to reset to.

refreshList

@Deprecated
public void refreshList(java.util.List<T> items)
Deprecated. 

Original method used to refresh to this. @#setList(List) should be used instead.

Parameters:
items - The items to reset the list to.
